Strengthening Gender Outcomes in Pacific COVID-19 
Response and Recovery (KSTA REG 54247) 
 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
The  regional  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  strengthen  the 
institutional and technical capacity for progressing gender equality outcomes in Pacific developing 
member  countries  (DMCs),  particularly  in  the  context  of  response  and  recovery  from  the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19). It will support Pacific DMCs to (i) identify gender mainstreaming 
opportunities and innovative and transformative gender projects and programs; (ii) strengthen 
DMC capacity to implement and monitor gender equality actions; and (iii) strengthen gender 
partnerships and knowledge among Pacific DMCs. The outcomes are directly linked to the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  Strategy  2030  (specifically  operational  priority  2  of  accelerating 
progress in gender equality) and Sustainable Development Goal 5 (achieve gender equality and 
empower all women and girls). It will be carried out from August 2020 until July 2025. ADB 
(through the Pacific Regional Department) will be the executing agency for the TA facility in close 
coordination with Pacific DMCs, executing and implementing agencies, resident missions and 
other development partners.   
 
The TA will require a minimum of 30 person-months of international and 96 person-months of 
national consulting services. International and national individual consultants will be engaged to 
support implementation of activities. Consulting firms, civil society organizations (CSOs), and/or 
training institutes may also be engaged for some of the activities. Detailed terms of reference 
(TORs) will be formulated depending on the government’s request during TA implementation. The 
selection and engagement of consultants will follow ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated staff instructions. TORs for individuals and/or firm(s) will be 
developed at TA implementation based on the specific needs of the DMCs.   
 
Output  1:  Gender-responsive  policies  and investments identified.  The  TA  will  provide 
technical expertise, assessments, and other analytical work to support at least three Pacific DMCs 
in identifying gender mainstreaming opportunities, and innovative and transformative gender 
projects and programs. There will be particular focus on assessing the ongoing gendered impacts 
of COVID-19 and defining policies and investments to counter these. In addition, strategic 
technical inputs will be provided in the following areas: (i) proactive gender design features in 
policy-based lending; (ii) develop innovative gender designs that support the scope of Sustainable 
Development Goal 5; and (iii) enhance gender analysis and formulation of gender action plans 
(GAPs) in projects that are particularly strategic for demonstrating the importance of gender 
mainstreaming, or projects that could be categorized ‘gender equity as a theme’ (GEN). 
 
Output  2:  Capacity  of  DMCs  to  implement  and  monitor  gender  equality  actions 
strengthened. The TA will help strengthen at least five DMCs’ capacity to implement, monitor, 
and report on gender equality activities and outcomes, including monitoring the gender results of 
Pacific operations under the COVID-19 Pandemic Response Option (CPRO’s). TA consultants 
will also provide targeted capacity development to executing agencies (EAs), implementing 
agencies (IAs), and national gender machineries through in-country or online briefings, training, 
and other support, as requested. The TA team will support the production of case studies on good 
practices in gender mainstreaming and the achievement of gender equality results. It will collect 
sex-disaggregated data and help Pacific DMCs to put in place stronger systems to collect such 
data.  
 
Output  3:  Gender  partnerships  strengthened  and  knowledge  products  produced  and 
shared. The TA will create knowledge solutions and strengthen partnerships to improve gender 
equality outcomes in the Pacific. It will work with stakeholders (including SPC) and governments 
to develop a research agenda and a knowledge product dissemination plan that meet the needs

of Pacific DMCs. A particular focus will be on gender-based violence (GBV) prevention and on 
developing gender knowledge products to inform the policies and plans for COVID-19 response 
and recovery. This output will support coordination and collaboration with the Pacific Partnership 
to develop and launch a Pacific regional GBV prevention hub and online portal. This will catalyze 
the investments made in GBV prevention to date, and build on existing partnerships in the Pacific 
to ensure sustainability. It will create a Pacific evidence base that highlights what works to prevent 
GBV, and fosters coordination and knowledge management among Pacific DMCs to ensure 
effective and evidence-based GBV prevention. To share knowledge and lessons, and to support 
learning and capacity development, the TA will also ensure that representatives of at least two 
Pacific DMCs participate in person or virtually in regional and/or global conferences, such as the 
United Nations Commission on the Status of Women and the triennial conference of Pacific 
Women and Pacific Women’s Ministers meeting.   
 
In  collaboration  with  ADB’s  Procurement,  Portfolio  and  Financial  Management  Department 
(PPFD), the TORs will be further refined with clear deliverables during TA implementation and 
may be varied to increase or alter the scope of services in line with government requests and any 
additional funds received by the TA. The precise number of experts and scope of services may 
vary and will be clarified during implementation. The TA scope is also expected to expand to cover 
additional activities, consistent with the TA’s outputs and outcome, and will be replenished from 
time to time as funds are required and identified, including those from cofinancing sources and 
ADB-administered trust funds. Accordingly, the nature and extent of consultants may increase 
and consultant contracts may be extended with corresponding budget increase subject to their 
satisfactory performance and continued availability.   
 
A: INTERNATIONAL CONSULTANTS 
 
International Gender Specialists (total of 30 person-months for individuals and/or firm[s]). The 
experts  will  support  DMCs  to  identify  gender  responsive  policies  and  investments  through 
assessments, policy support and development of knowledge products. Consultants will have a 
university degree in international development, a social science and/or gender studies, or related 
fields; at least 10 years of experience working in the field of gender and development; experience 
working in crisis/emergencies – preferably in the Pacific; and experience in gender research, 
including primary data collection. Full terms of reference of each consultant will be developed 
during TA implementation and based on DMCs needs. Tasks will include: 
(i)   undertaking primary and secondary research on gender and specific sectors (e.g. 
infrastructure, energy, urban development, public sector management); 
(ii)   assisting ADB and DMCs to prepare gender sensitive and gender responsive project 
documents; 
(iii)  overseeing/carrying out research on the gendered impacts of COVID-19 in selected 
Pacific DMCs. Identify entry points for gender responsive policies and programs related 
to COVID-19 response and recovery; 
(iv)  providing appropriate technical advice and policy recommendations to support gender 
responsive COVID-19 response and recovery measures; 
(v)   identifying  new  opportunities  on  emerging  sectors,  SDG  5  areas  and  explore 
innovations related to gender and development. Identify investments which should be 
prioritized.  
(vi)  providing policy support, training and capacity development to Pacific DMCs on specific 
gender needs (e.g. gender responsive budgeting); and 
(vii)  preparing knowledge products based on the findings of the assessments and analysis 
for dissemination to Pacific DMCs

3 
 
B: NATIONAL CONSULTANTS  
 
(i) Individual GBV Prevention consultants (2 nationals, 24 person-months) 
 
The national experts will support in developing and launching a regional GBV prevention hub in 
collaboration with Pacific DMCs and the Pacific Partnership.1 Consultants will have a university 
degree in international development, a social science and/or gender studies, or related fields; and  
at last 5 years of experience working in the field of gender and development – preferably in the 
field  of  GBV  programming  and/or  research;  and  experience  working  on  knowledge  and 
communication products. Full terms of reference of each consultant will be developed during TA 
implementation.  Tasks will include the following: 
(i)   coordination  with  Pacific  DMCs  and  regional  stakeholders  including  the  Pacific 
Partnership to develop a ToR and workplan for the establishment of the regional GBV 
prevention hub.  
(ii)   carrying  out  capacity  and  knowledge  surveys  with  Pacific  DMCs,  civil  society, 
government agencies, development partners, academic institutions, and other relevant 
organizations to ascertain key gaps in GBV prevention  
(iii)  carry out a review of projects, programs and research on GBV Prevention in the Pacific 
(iii)  develop priority initiatives and knowledge products to meet the gaps highlighted in the 
reviews 
(iv)  support the design of the online hub 
(v)   support launch of the GBV Prevention hub and online portal through developing 
communication material, press releases and training 
(vi)  monitor usage and uptake of materials/support on online portal 
 
(ii) Individual Gender capacity building consultants RM-based (2 nationals, 24 person 
months) 
 
The National Gender and Development Consultants will be based in PNG resident mission 
(PNRM) and Pacific Subregional Office (SPSO), Fiji, and will support Pacific DMCs to monitor 
and report on gender equality outcomes. Consultants will have a university degree in international 
development, a social science and/or gender studies, or related fields; experience working in 
monitoring and evaluation – preferably with a focus on gender programs/projects and; experience 
of capacity development and delivering training. Full terms of reference of each consultant will be 
developed during TA implementation.  Tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  regularly coordinate and provide technical advice and support to relevant government 
staff  in  EAs,  IAs  and  project  gender  consultants/focal  points  to  ensure  effective 
implementation and monitoring of ADB project Gender Action Plans (GAPs). This may 
include  capacity  develop  for  Pacific  DMCs  in  gender  and  GAP  implementation, 
monitoring and reporting.  
(ii)   support Pacific DMCs to monitor ADB COVID-19 projects and programs 
(iii)  take part in loan review missions to monitor progress towards achieving gender and 
development objectives 
(iv)  strengthen  collaboration  on  gender  with  governments,  national  women’s  groups, 
intergovernmental and aid agencies, research institutions, civil society, development 
partners and other stakeholders in the country;

(v) contribute to the creation of knowledge products on gender and development, including 
case studies, blogs, gender briefings, and regular country specific gender updates 
 
(iii) Firm/civil society/training institute (7 national, 30 person-months, intermittent) 
 
National consulting firms/CSOs/training institutes may also be engaged in the implementation of 
the TA. Full terms of reference of will be developed during TA implementation and in consultation 
with Pacific DMCs. They will be responsible for: 
(i)  producing assessments on the gendered impact of COVID-19 in selected Pacific DMCs 
and make recommendations on entry points to support gender responsive COVID-19 
response  and  recovery  measures.  Studies  will  include  collection  and  analysis  of 
secondary and primary data across sectors.  
(ii) providing appropriate technical advice, policy recommendations and trainings to develop 
gender  responsive  COVID-19  measures,  including  improving  collection  of  sex 
disaggregated data. 
(iii) assessing existing systems for collection of sex-disaggregated data in crisis/emergency 
response  and  make  recommendations  for  strengthening  sex-disaggregated  data 
collection and analysis.  
(iv) supporting Pacific DMCs to collect sex disaggregated data for ADB COVID-19 projects 
and programs.  
(v) preparing knowledge products based on the findings of the assessments and analysis 
for dissemination to Pacific DMCs 
 
(iv) Senior national TA coordinator (national, 18 person months) 
 
The senior TA coordinator will work closely with ADB staff and the TA consultants in implementing 
the TA. The coordinator must have (i) a university degree in international development, a social 
science and/or gender studies, or related fields; (ii) at least 5 years of relevant experience in TA 
administration; and (iii) excellent oral and written communication skills in English. The consultant 
will be based in ADB headquarters.  
 
Tasks will include the following: a) assist the TA team in the day-to-day coordination and 
monitoring of TA outputs, activities and implementation; b) coordinate logistical arrangements of 
knowledge events and products under this TA; and c) perform other tasks as reasonably required: 
(i)   develop and update the Pacific Department (PARD) processing and implementation 
databases 
(ii)   coordinate with PARD front office to update project gender mainstreaming categories 
for processing  
(iii)   provide regular updates on performance against department and corporate targets 
(iv)   review and provide substantive inputs to progress monitoring and completion reports 
including regular project GAP updates; Summary of Gender Equality Results (e.g, 
Gender Annex to Project Completion Reports (PCRs)) at project completion; and 
gender inputs to project mission report, including Aide Memoire or Memorandum of 
Understanding (MOU), and Back To Office Reports (BTORs). This includes providing 
technical guidance, substantive comments and edits, especially in the PCRs and their 
Gender Annex;  
(v)  participate  in  relevant  project  review  missions  to  guide  and  assist 
executing/implementing agencies on GAP implementation; assist in the preparation 
of quality GAP monitoring reports; provide gender inputs to mission reports and

ensure actions related to ADB gender commitments and agreements are documented 
for consistent follow-up;  
(vi)   develop  and  assist  in  the  production  of  gender-related  knowledge  products  for 
electronic, paper or other publication formats, including online newsletters, blogs, and 
vlogs. Also coordinate with gender specialists in the resident missions and relevant 
project officers for the production of gender-related knowledge products;  
(vii)  logistical support including support for conferences and events 
(viii)  report on, administer, and regularly monitor the progress of the implementation of the 
regional TA facility. This includes but is not limited to coordinating and supporting 
recruitment of consultants and the conduct of TA activities including technical review 
of deliverables under this TA and prepare the final draft of the TA completion report;  
(ix)   any other task as required by the supervisor, to contribute towards the effective 
implementation,  monitoring  and  reporting  of  gender  mainstreamed  projects  and 
successful achievement of TA results.
